urn:contentItem:6C1V-7011-JBJ7-N0MM-00000-00Pandering to vested interests risks undermining society's cohesion2024-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisPandering to vested interests risks undermining society's cohesion

Readers comment on how governments beholden to vested interests threaten the fabric of society when the budget pie favours the powerful over the needy.

Link to Image

Illustration: Megan Herbert

To submit a letter to The Age, email letters@theage.com.au. Please include your home address and telephone number below your letter. No attachments. See here for our rules and tips on getting your letter published.

VESTED INTERESTS

For many years, the ability of Commonwealth governments to frame good budgets has been hamstrung by a lack of courage to take on vested interests, and by the politics of fear.Generous negative gearing and capital gains concessions have contributed to the housing affordability crisis, at a cost to the budget of $60 billion over 10 years ("Unable to crack the housing market, I went looking for cocaine", 15/5). But governments have not addressed this sacred cow due to the fear campaign drummed up by the Morrison government in 2019.Western Australia, awash with mining royalties, will continue to get special GST revenue handouts to shore up political support in that state. Rich and powerful mining companies will continue to drain Commonwealth revenues through their exemption from excise duty on their off-road use of diesel fuel.Hundreds of millions ($604 million in 2024-25) will be spent holding a few asylum seekers in difficult conditions on Nauru, when their claims should be processed in places like Indonesia so that they have no incentive to get on boats.The JobSeeker allowance remains unchanged, way below the pension rate, but high-income earners will get generous tax cuts and the $300 household energy subsidy on July 1.Private schools, many replete with first-class facilities, will continue to get generous support while many government schools struggle.At some stage soon, an Australian government will need to address the concessions to vested interests in order to shore up government revenues and support the needy.

Otherwise, inequalities will widen and undermine our society's cohesion.Andrew Trembath, Blackburn,

Fossil fuel producers before disaster mitigationSubsidies to fossil fuel producers from federal and state governments have increased to $14.5 billion in the 2023/24 financial year. It seems our leaders continue to value fossil fuels over our climate, or our preparedness for disasters - by a factor of 16.Lesley Walker, Northcote

Rein in the money flowing to the west, from the eastThe ridiculous GST allocations to the resource rich WA must cease. That state has had enough bolstering up on the backs of the eastern states. Its very rich mining magnates bear witness to the mismanagement of the mineral sector, time for that to stop as well. Equity must be achieved, especially for the workers in those mining industries.Doris LeRoy, Altona

The $300 pays for my fire and flood insurance hikeThanks for the $300 Mr Chalmers. It will just cover the 20 per cent increase in my home and contents insurance which is due to more devastating floods and bushfires caused by climate change which your government appears not to address.Thomas Upton, Kennington

Now it's time to finally say somethingFirst they came for coal power, but I didn't know the source of our electricity, so I said nothing.Then they came for changed electricity supply arrangements that benefit intermittent power. But, I didn't know this, so I said nothing. Then they subsidised roof solar power, but I had some, so I said nothing.With fanfare, they subsidised big solar and big wind, and they told me my electricity bill would go down, so I said nothing.Perversely they are now subsidising coal to keep it running, but they kept this quiet, so I said nothing.Now in the budget, with an energy rebate, they are subsidising me, a consumer and taxpayer. I finally realised I was paying again, and again, all up twice, or was it three times or more?"I need to say something!" (Acknowledging Martin Niemoller, 1946).David Brunt, Northcote

THE FORUM

Uni protestsDr Alan Finkel (″⁣Students have a right to protest. Peacefully.″⁣ 16/5) asks why universities are being so roundly criticised. While defending their role in defence of free speech, he ignores a major reason for the current pro-Palestine actions.The students involved are calling for their universities to get out of research with Israeli weapons and surveillance companies and institutions while their government bombs Gaza into a dystopian future and continues its inhuman occupation of Palestinian territories.Their protests are timely, show up the pusillanimous Albanese government, and deserve our support.Ken Blackman, Inverloch

Gonski model failThe public education system has a higher proportion of students with disabilities than the non-government sector, ("Disability forces school funding rise", 16/5). The usual response to this fact is a justifiable demand for more money, but there is another issue here, which is the disproportion itself, which arises because of the Gonski funding model flaws that we are not allowed to mention.On the one hand, the Gonski model provides the full loadings for disadvantage, including disability, for all students, no matter the sector, thus encouraging non-government schools to take more such students. On the other hand, the schooling resource standard for non-government schools is adjusted according to each school's median parental income, forcing many schools to put their fees up and drive disadvantaged students out of them into the government sector, increasing social stratification and lowering overall educational achievement.Gonski is a dud model and it needs to be replaced by a model that adjusts the funding of non-governments schools according to the fees they charge so that they are supported - and even required - to take more disadvantaged students.Chris Curtis, Hurstbridge

School behaviourHaving undertaken many years of teacher training in Australia, and 40 years of being a leader in teacher education as a practising teacher and academic here and in the UK, I think I am qualified to ask why Britain's ″⁣school behaviour chief″⁣ (surely a post derived from a need occasioned by poor school behaviour), is listened to after ″⁣visiting Australian schools this week″⁣. (″⁣School Behaviour Chief's clear message for teachers″⁣, 15/5). The former Soho nightclub owner left his teacher training feeling unprepared to manage a classroom. This, in itself, may be a result of factors other than a failure of the British teacher education system. There is no such thing as a single ″⁣classroom″⁣ to be fully prepared for.Australian classrooms are diverse. An increasing number of children and students are being asked to learn in a language, English, which is new to them. We have an exam system which is antiquated, and a curriculum which to many children of the digital age seems purposeless.Bad behaviour is not just a matter of bad manners, though all teachers agree that respect and routines are essential for successful classroom learning.The visiting behaviour chief's assertion that current Australian graduates are underskilled, and that this could be traced back to university academics who ″⁣promulgated all types of odd bizarre actions about behaviour″⁣, is at best, ignorant, and at worst, absurd.Australian educational experts would, no doubt, agree that many children, are indeed, behaving badly. Their message, based on Australian experience, would surely be that if we are to change behaviour, we need a whole-society approach.This would include such measures as control of social media; ways of dealing with childhood mental illness; equality of resourcing for public and private schools; parenting support; and, importantly, a recognition that a monolingual delivery of the curriculum disadvantages many students. Sadly, teacher education, however poor or excellent, is neither the demon, nor the panacea for school behaviour.Kay Moulton, Surrey Hill

Greater glider deathRe ″⁣Endangered greater glider found dead next to department's felling site″⁣, 15/5. I was there yesterday when the still warm body of this greater glider was found.I'm a member of the community group that successfully took VicForests to court for failing to protect endangered greater gliders during its logging operations. This win was the result of endless hours of evidence-gathering in the forest at night where I came to know and love these beautiful, gentle creatures.It's devastating that we now have an organisation, Forest Fire Management Victoria, that can log without any environmental oversight.Volunteers had sent detection reports to FFMV of greater gliders and Leadbeater's' possums in the very trees that were marked for removal, but these were ignored.As the Officer of the Conservation Regulator has said in an email, ″⁣Decisions around DEECA's fire operations, including assurance, are managed through the department″⁣. This does not augur well for what's left of our forest wildlife.Rosemary Storey, St Andrews

Firefighter lives firstDangerous trees are one of the most serious risks faced by firefighters, and tragically a volunteer lost his life at the Black Saturday Murrindindi fire in 2009. Two firefighters also lost their lives at the Harrietville fire in 2013 from falling trees.It beggars belief that the Victorian National Parks Association and Environmental Justice Australia puts the loss of one greater glider ahead of protecting firefighters who have to work in potentially extremely dangerous conditions to control bushfires - bushfires that ironically can destroy vast swathes of habitat for greater gliders and Leadbeater's' possums.The loss of a few hollow-bearing trees along strategic firebreaks is a small price to pay, particularly when there are tens of thousands of hectares of forest with hollow-bearing trees remaining untouched.Peter Farrell, Point Lonsdale

Pay for your car privilegeIt is hard to have sympathy for people who buy or rent inner-city apartments with no parking, who then complain about not being able to park their cars ("Drivers 'fighting in the streets' over car spaces", 14/5). As a former resident of an inner Sydney suburb, I know that properties with off-street parking, or access to a resident parking scheme, sell or rent at a premium to those that do not.The inner suburbs of Melbourne and Sydney were designed around public transport and walking, not cars. It is just not feasible for everyone to own a car. If you want to live in an inner suburb and own a car, then you must be prepared to pay extra for the privilege.James Proctor, Maiden Gully

Bring on tram extensionsI was impressed and pleased to read the article regarding completing the 50-metre "missing link", ("The 50-metre 'missing link' fix that will open new cross-city tram routes", 16/5), which will provide an additional, vital east-west link to our tram network.There are other quick wins and tweaks to be had around Melbourne that can further improve the network and increase flexibility in operation.For example, the route 48 to North Balwyn should be extended up to Doncaster Shoppingtown and the route 70 extended to Deakin University via Elgar Road to link up with the route 75, and the 64 extended down Nepean Highway to Southland and so on.Once the Metro Tunnel opens, there is scope, I believe, to reroute some of the St Kilda tram routes and/or introduce some inner-city short workings running north to south. For example, the 67 Carnegie could be routed via Chapel, Church and Swan Streets into the city via Flinders or Collins Street using existing pointwork.Steven Haby, Hughesdale

Insecure menI greatly appreciated your theatre critic Cameron Woodhead's interview with Trophy Boys playwright Emmanuelle Mattana. Its nuanced analysis of insecure masculinity that hides behind the traditional dominant and abusive masculinity that boys in many parts of our society learn.(″⁣Schoolboys ranked this smart young woman. Her response is thrilling,″⁣ 15/5).As a boy, I went to a private boys school in Sydney and felt I could never be ″⁣man enough″⁣. I was the soft boy that never fitted into the dominant image of what a man had to be.I found the pictures in the Trophy Boy play that showed the physical posturing that boys learn confronting, as they brought back memories and feelings of the dominant masculinity I could never live up to.We need to continue to have conversations about this dominant and patriarchal form of masculinity and explore alternative forms of manhood. Men (and boys) need models that will help them embrace more of their feminine side. Men insecure in their own masculine identity will attack, abuse and denigrate those who express a softer, more human form of masculinity that is balanced with femininity.These men deny their femininity, and will project their feelings of weakness onto others as they work to dominate and hide their insecurities.With women, they will use tactics to make them objects they can rate to give themselves a sense of power over others (as happened at Yarra Valley Grammar).In conversation, they dominate and compete with others, especially women, to assert their fragile hypermasculinity. The incident with the boys at Yarra Valley Grammar highlights the need for our society (including schools, football clubs, business leaders etc.) to work at how we educate our boys to be real men.Bruce Hart, Bittern

AND ANOTHER THING ...

Link to Image

Illustration: Matt Golding

Morrison's visitScott Morrison has met Donald Trump to focus on AUKUS in a "warm and friendly" visit about such issues - when they are no longer in power. Seems a bit Mad Hatter's tea party to me.Glenda Johnston, Queenscliff

You can tell a man by the company he keeps. For Donald Trump it was a porn star, for Scott Morrison it was Donald Trump.Stephen Farrelly, Donvale

EconomyHuge song and dance over $9.40 per week increase in the Commonwealth rent allowance of $94 per week. Median rent in Melbourne in the December quarter was $530.00 a week. Good luck finding one.Rob Gordon, Brighton

Boomers to subsidise continued rent relief for Millennials to indulge their inner CBD lifestyle.George Reed, Wheelers Hill,

Why has the government set a tertiary attainment target of 80 percent by 2050, but no target has been set for trades qualified people. Isn't the lack of trades qualified people our current problem?Howard Brownscombe, Brighton

FurthermoreWhy do we keep seeing ″⁣former Jetstar pilot″⁣ in the media? We don't see ″⁣former tram driver Joe Bloggs″⁣. Does this mean the man in question is somehow special? It's fast becoming an unnecessary cliche.Courtney Pern, East Malvern

The first impression of the portrait of King Charles suggests a monarchy steeped in blood and representing the brutal colonial policies, starting in Ireland, perpetrated by Britain over centuries. Quite apt.Máire Mills, Alfredton

FinallyA way to get students out of university building sit-ins (″⁣Classes cancelled as university stand-off with pro-Palestine protesters continues″⁣, 16/5) would be superannuated academics delivering lectures on ancient Icelandic sagas, alternating with broadcasts of popular songs of the 1950s.Sandra Torpey, Hawthorn

urn:contentItem:68DH-PJ41-JBJ7-N00T-00000-00Female-specific cancers to be added to firefighter compensation scheme2023-06-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisFemale-specific cancers to be added to firefighter compensation scheme

The changes will also apply to female mechanics employed by fire services and women who work in forest fire prevention, which the firefighters union opposes.

Female-specific diseases such as cervical, ovarian and uterine cancers will be added to the list of conditions that are automatically presumed to be caused by professional firefighting, under a plan to be unveiled by the Andrews government on Friday.

A cabinet minister, who was briefed on the changes earlier this week, said the incoming reforms would extend to female firefighters, female mechanics employed by fire services and women who work in forest fire prevention.

Link to Image

Jason South

"It's taken a while, but we're getting it done," said the senior Labor MP, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss government matters.

The government promised former Derryn Hinch Justice Party MP Tania Maxwell two years ago that it would add female-specific cancers to the existing workers' compensation scheme.

Under the scheme, if a professional firefighter develops cancer it is presumed to be as a result of their profession - effectively reversing the traditional onus of proof. About 5000 paid firefighters are covered, as are some 90 maintenance staff.

The reform, which could be brought before parliament within weeks, will likely reignite tensions between Labor and the professional firefighters' body.

While the United Firefighters Union (UFU) is supportive of expanding the number of cancers covered by the laws, it has long campaigned against them applying to employees who work on vehicle and equipment maintenance.

Personal injury lawyers have previously warned the inclusion of people who aren't firefighters could make it easier for insurers to challenge claims because mechanics are exposed to fewer risks from toxic fumes. The government has insisted maintenance workers who attend fires should have the same rights as professional firefighters.

UFU boss Peter Marshall on Wednesday called for an urgent parliamentary inquiry.

"The presumptive cancer legislation that supports professional firefighters is underpinned by comprehensive scientific medical research, which establishes the link between the occupation of firefighting and cancer," he said.

"By ignoring that scientific evidence and expanding presumptive cancer legislation to non-firefighters, the Andrews government is putting the integrity of those laws at risk."

Geelong-based firefighter Katherine Dunell, who has been present at major chemical blazes, told The Age: "Mechanics don't go into burning buildings. Firefighters do."

However, she said she wanted to see female-specific cancers added to existing laws. Testicular and prostate cancers are already covered by Victoria's scheme.

"At the moment, female firefighters, who do the same job as their male counterparts, do not have the same presumptive cancer protections in place," she said.

Dunell said she was not aware of any female firefighters in Victoria with cancer, but did know of one in Western Australia who wasn't covered by presumptive cancer laws. There were just over 20 women firefighters in Victoria as of 2019.

The Greens unveiled their own bill on Wednesday, arguing that the government had taken too long to close the "gender medical data gap". That bill focuses on covering firefighters with primary site ovarian, cervical and uterine cancer once they've been in the job for a decade.

Asked if the party was open to supporting legislation that covered female mechanics, Greens leader Samantha Ratnam said: "This is the reform that we're putting on the table."

The UFU has called on Labor to support the Greens' bill. During last year's state election, the union urged voters to put government candidates last in key seats, including Richmond, which Labor lost to the Greens.

Marshall campaigned for Premier Daniel Andrews in 2014, but the pair later had a public falling out over controversial fire services reforms, which included presumptive cancer laws.

Andrews rubbished the Greens on Wednesday, describing the party as the "commentators in the cheap seats".

"We won't be having to rely upon a Green political party bill," he said. "Let me make it clear: we will have more to say about this, and it'll have precisely nothing to do with the Green political party.

"I'm not at liberty to talk about matters that cabinet may well have considered a couple of days ago, for instance. That's not appropriate. But announcements will be made in due course."

In response, Ratnam said the Greens had been championing these reforms for more than a decade.

"We really welcome more and more people getting on board so we can have a multi-partisan agreement on this," she said.

urn:contentItem:68DH-PJ41-JBJ7-N025-00000-00Female-specific cancers to be added to firefighter compensation scheme2023-06-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisFemale-specific cancers to be added to firefighter compensation scheme

The changes will also apply to female mechanics employed by fire services and women who work in forest fire prevention, which the firefighters union opposes.

Female-specific diseases such as cervical, ovarian and uterine cancers will be added to the list of conditions that are automatically presumed to be caused by professional firefighting, under a plan to be unveiled by the Andrews government on Friday.

A cabinet minister, who was briefed on the changes earlier this week, said the incoming reforms would extend to female firefighters, female mechanics employed by fire services and women who work in forest fire prevention.

Link to Image

Jason South

"It's taken a while, but we're getting it done," said the senior Labor MP, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss government matters.

The government promised former Derryn Hinch Justice Party MP Tania Maxwell two years ago that it would add female-specific cancers to the existing workers' compensation scheme.

Under the scheme, if a professional firefighter develops cancer it is presumed to be as a result of their profession - effectively reversing the traditional onus of proof. About 5000 paid firefighters are covered, as are some 90 maintenance staff.

The reform, which could be brought before parliament within weeks, will likely reignite tensions between Labor and the professional firefighters' body.

While the United Firefighters Union (UFU) is supportive of expanding the number of cancers covered by the laws, it has long campaigned against them applying to employees who work on vehicle and equipment maintenance.

Personal injury lawyers have previously warned the inclusion of people who aren't firefighters could make it easier for insurers to challenge claims because mechanics are exposed to fewer risks from toxic fumes. The government has insisted maintenance workers who attend fires should have the same rights as professional firefighters.

UFU boss Peter Marshall on Wednesday called for an urgent parliamentary inquiry.

"The presumptive cancer legislation that supports professional firefighters is underpinned by comprehensive scientific medical research, which establishes the link between the occupation of firefighting and cancer," he said.

"By ignoring that scientific evidence and expanding presumptive cancer legislation to non-firefighters, the Andrews government is putting the integrity of those laws at risk."

Geelong-based firefighter Katherine Dunell, who has been present at major chemical blazes, told The Age: "Mechanics don't go into burning buildings. Firefighters do."

However, she said she wanted to see female-specific cancers added to existing laws. Testicular and prostate cancers are already covered by Victoria's scheme.

"At the moment, female firefighters, who do the same job as their male counterparts, do not have the same presumptive cancer protections in place," she said.

Dunell said she was not aware of any female firefighters in Victoria with cancer, but did know of one in Western Australia who wasn't covered by presumptive cancer laws. There were just over 20 women firefighters in Victoria as of 2019.

The Greens unveiled their own bill on Wednesday, arguing that the government had taken too long to close the "gender medical data gap". That bill focuses on covering firefighters with primary site ovarian, cervical and uterine cancer once they've been in the job for a decade.

Asked if the party was open to supporting legislation that covered female mechanics, Greens leader Samantha Ratnam said: "This is the reform that we're putting on the table."

The UFU has called on Labor to support the Greens' bill. During last year's state election, the union urged voters to put government candidates last in key seats, including Richmond, which Labor lost to the Greens.

Marshall campaigned for Premier Daniel Andrews in 2014, but the pair later had a public falling out over controversial fire services reforms, which included presumptive cancer laws.

Andrews rubbished the Greens on Wednesday, describing the party as the "commentators in the cheap seats".

"We won't be having to rely upon a Green political party bill," he said. "Let me make it clear: we will have more to say about this, and it'll have precisely nothing to do with the Green political party.

"I'm not at liberty to talk about matters that cabinet may well have considered a couple of days ago, for instance. That's not appropriate. But announcements will be made in due course."

In response, Ratnam said the Greens had been championing these reforms for more than a decade.

"We really welcome more and more people getting on board so we can have a multi-partisan agreement on this," she said.

"One of our jobs as the Greens in the Victorian parliament is to push the government to go further and faster at every opportunity on progressive reforms."

While shadow cabinet has not yet discussed Labor's plans or the Greens bill, the government's changes are expected to pass the upper house given the opposition did not oppose previous expansions of the presumptive cancer scheme.

The Coalition's emergency services spokeswoman, Ann-Marie Hermans, told The Age that all firefighters, regardless of their sex, deserve to be supported by "appropriate" presumptive cancer laws.

urn:contentItem:699T-9DV1-JD3N-5205-00000-00Allan must regain trust of the regions2023-10-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Allan must regain trust of the regionsPETER HUNT

ANALYSIS Will new Premier Jacinta Allan pull her party back from inner urban battles to refocus on workers and communities beyond the goat-cheese belt, asks PETER HUNT Timber workers, CFA volunteers, hunters, farmers and their irrigation communities must be hoping that as Member for Bendigo East, Premier Jacinta Allan rebuilds her government's fractured relationship with regional communities.

Daniel Andrews will have schooled Ms Allan in the game of numbers, managing the party and keeping the Greens at bay in Northcote, Preston, Footscray and Pascoe Vale.

But the new Premier can prove she is no Dan Andrews by re-engaging regional voters and those in Labor's heartland electorates.

A mountain of debt means the era of florescent vests and hard-hat politics is coming to an end. Even scrapping together the funds needed to rebuild and pave the state's broken road network will be a challenge.

However, Ms Allan can still hit the ground running by terminating Labor's green-leaning policies that have so damaged regional communities.

Dismissing the push by one Animal Justice Party MP and a handful of green-leaning Labor colleagues to ban duck hunting would be a good first step, especially when hunters are willing to adopt shooter proficiency testing to curb wounding rates.

The Premier also needs to step in on the wild-dog debate, where her Agriculture and Environment Ministers seem to be kowtowing to the AJP's demands.

The order allowing baiting and trapping of the predators on crown land has only been extended for 12 months, while the government investigates the AJP's claims that most wild dogs are purebred dingoes.

Regional Victoria also needs a Premier who listens to farmers whose land is about to be carved up by 500kV transmission lines, and challenges the Australian Energy Market Regulator's refusal to instead consider upgrading 220kV lines along existing easements.

Then there's the more immediate issue of ensuring Victoria is prepared for major fires over the next two summers.

Timber harvest and haulage crews need to be given the certainty of permanent contracts to bring their heavy machinery in to fight fires.

The Code of Practice for Timber Production needs to be amended to end environmental groups' green lawfare, which has stopped firewood cutters from salvaging a ticking fire bomb of 600,000 windblown trees left lying on the Wombat Forest floor since June 2021.

Voters in Ms Allan's own electorate, who rely on firewood for heating, are already seeing the impact of firewood shortages.

Meanwhile, the CFA needs the resources to recruit more volunteers and funding to rebuild the nation's oldest tanker fleet.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is also battling to curb fuel loads in the face of onerous regulations and lack of resourcing.

Ms Allan should not cave in to the United Firefighters Union's demands for pay rises of up to 7 per cent annually and a share of $117 million in supposed efficiency savings from Fire Rescue Victoria taking control of 38 CFA stations.

Ms Allan will also have to back Victoria's claim that it opposes federal water buyouts of Victorian irrigation communities' water, with action, especially when she has irrigators sitting across the north of her electorate.

As drought creeps across Victoria, the Premier will have to draw on her experience during the millennium drought as Regional and Rural Development Minister from 2007 to 2010 and then as opposition agriculture spokeswoman from 2013 to 2014 to keep regional communities resilient and safe. The last thing Ms Allan wants is to front yet another Royal Commission to explain why so little was done under her watch.

urn:contentItem:6992-95K1-JD34-V0MB-00000-00Corryong prepared to welcome record numbers for emergency expo2023-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisCorryong prepared to welcome record numbers for emergency expoBeau Greenway

A biennial event highlighting services provided before, during and after an emergency has attracted a record number of exhibitors.

North East Emergency Action Group is thrilled with the response to its fourth North East Emergency Expo, with 30 different organisations to feature at Corryong Recreation Reserve on Saturday, October 14.

The previous high was 18 at the second edition of the expo held at Moyhu in 2018, but with the Upper Murray impacted by both bushfires and floods in the past three years, demand for services has increased.

"I think the Corryong community, especially, is really keen to have an event like this. They know people will come to their aid in an emergency, but it will show them how they can help cope after an emergency and who's actually out there for them," North East Emergency Action Group president Carina Newton said.

"We've had a lot more advertising than previous times because we were lucky enough to land two funding grants.

"We've got a TV ad and we've got more banners and posters out there. That's allowed us to get the word out, and other participating groups are sharing it as well, so that has sparked some interest."

Ms Newton said a large contingent of fire services, including CFA, NSW Rural Fire Service and NSW Fire and Rescue would be on hand for the event.

"There's definitely lots to see and do," Ms Newton said.

"We just hope it doesn't rain. It hasn't rained at one expo yet.

"There's a lot of rain predicted beforehand, but not on the day. Hopefully the oval will be dried out enough so we can get the trucks on there."

Agriculture Victoria, Angel Flight Australia, Australian Preppers Survival League, Corryong Health, Department of Families, Fairness and Housing, Fire and Rescue Victoria's crisis response dog, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Hume Riverina Community Legal Services, NSW and Victoria SES units, St John Ambulance, Snowy Hydro, THRIVE, Towong Shire Council, Upper Murray Youth, Victorian Council of Churches Emergencies Ministry and Victoria and NSW Police will also be in attendance.

A range of food and beverage stalls will operate throughout the day.

The expo is scheduled from 10am to 3pm, with a gold coin donation for entry.

For more information, visit the North East Emergency Action Group website or email expo@neeag.org.au

The event started at Whorouly in 2016 before it was taken to Moyhu (2018) and Nagambie (2021).

urn:contentItem:693R-1KW1-F0J6-J02D-00000-00Lessons from Black Summer shape training for season2023-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Lessons from Black Summer shape training for seasonBeau Greenway

With the North East bracing for another severe fire season, emergency services have been sharpening up on their preparations with simulated incident responses.

More than 50 people attended an exercise at the CFA's West Wodonga incident control centre yesterday, based on a fast-moving grass fire to the east of Wodonga, to ensure all agencies could put those skills into practice in a real life situation.

SES, CFA, Victoria Police, VicRoads and Department of Education were among the services represented.

Assistant chief fire officer Paul King said experiences from the 2019-2020 Black Summer bushfires and recent flood responses in the region helped shape the training.

"It's been well communicated that we're in for a difficult fire season. The El Nino weather conditions are returning, which means a longer, hotter, drier summer," he said.

"Whilst it's still quite wet in the landscape now, we expect that when the rain stops in spring, that fuel will dry out really quickly, especially the grass fuels.

"People say 'it's just a grass fire' but grass fires are incredibly fast, they are unpredictable and dangerous and they can cause catastrophic damage.

"We're expecting that we'll have initially a very difficult grass fire season, just with the amount of grass caused by those wet conditions, then turning into hotter weather.

"That may lead into forest fire conditions later in the season.

"We've had major emergencies in the last couple of years, but we haven't had a significant fire season for about three years now. Whilst we're practising managing and responding to emergencies, generally they've been floods, but fires pose different risks to us."

Mr King said response teams were "getting better every time" by running the exercises before a fire season arrives.

"The 2019-2020 fire season was devastating in the North East and we learned a lot of things from that about how we work with community, how we get access back into fire areas and how we protect people that are stuck in the fire area," he said.

"I'd like to think we get better every year, and, in fact, this exercise today is based on some of the lessons that we've learned from previous fires and the way we managed the floods.

"That's how we script these exercises, to capitalise on the lessons learned in the past."

VICSES operations manager Neil Payn relished the opportunity to be the incident controller of the scenario.

"I'm currently an endorsed level three incident controller, but I'm an SES staff member so my experience has mainly been in floods, storms and earthquakes," he said,

"This is my first opportunity working as an incident controller in a fire. I have worked in an incident management team for a fire before, but only assisting.

"These are critical to our business. We've got to exercise regularly, so it keeps people fresh and you're always learning."

The CFA can declare a fire danger period as early as October in some regions, which can remain in place for more than six months.

urn:contentItem:68MP-WW81-F0J6-J3NH-00000-00Illegal firewood warning2023-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Illegal firewood warningVera Demertzis

Residents have been asked to be vigilant when it comes illegal firewood in the winter months as authorities crack down on illegal tree felling.

Department of Energy, Environment and Climate officers are currently investigating several instances of illegally felled trees in the Ballarat and Ararat areas.

Hotspots for illegal firewood collection in the Grampians region include Ararat Regional Park, Creswick State Forest, and the Inverleigh Flora Reserve.

A Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action spokesperson said the illegal removal of firewood was serious issue.

"Illegally taking firewood from the forest causes significant environmental damage and habitat loss," they said. "It is a serious issue in the midlands area around Ararat and further out into central and western Victoria."

Victorians can help protect the environment by sourcing their firewood responsibly.

There are free designated collection areas open during autumn and spring for people looking to collect their own firewood, and if they're looking to buy firewood, we urge people to use reputable sellers.

"The Conservation Regulator relies on the community's help to solve environmental crimes and encourages anyone with information about illegal felling of trees, firewood theft or suspicious firewood sellers to report it to 136 186."

The illegal removal of firewood from public land has negative impacts on the health of our forests, wildlife habitat and the sustainability of firewood resources for the community.

Anyone caught breaking firewood collection rules faces a maximum penalty of $9615 and/or a year in prison if prosecuted in court.

Equipment such as chainsaws and trailers can also be seized.

Threatened native species, including the powerful owl, greater glider, and brush-tailed phascogale, rely on the trees and hollows in state forests and parks for habitat and illegal tree felling risks their survival.

The Conservation Regulator is targeting the illegal take of firewood through Operation Hollows, a joint state-wide operation with Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria, that utilises regular patrols across public land, and intelligence-gathering methods such as concealed cameras and community reports.

The Conservation Regulator is aware that timber taken illegally from these areas could be sold on to the community.

The public is asked to be vigilant when purchasing firewood by asking where the wood comes from, requesting a receipt and questioning if the wood seems too cheap.

For more information, visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood/firewood-collection-in-your-region

urn:contentItem:67KY-3VX1-DYG0-90WM-00000-00VIC:Uncontrolled fire growing north of Melbourne2023-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Uncontrolled fire growing north of MelbourneMELBOURNE Feb 22

  A large, fast-moving and uncontrolled grassfire north of Melbourne is growing and heading towards more towns.
   The blaze started at Flowerdale, about 90 minutes from the Victorian capital, on Tuesday afternoon and is burning north towards Yea.


   Waterbombing aircraft were used overnight and it's believed no homes have been impacted but the full extent of damage to fences and sheds is unknown.
   The fire is more than 700 hectares in size and burning across steep, inaccessible terrain towards forested areas.
   An emergency warning is in place for Flowerdale meaning it is too late for many residents to leave.
   However those located between Dairy Creek Road and Handleys Road and Upper King Parrot Creek Road and Landmark Lane have been told to go before conditions get worse.
   Smoke is visible across the areas and an incident control centre has been set up at Alexandra.
   More than 50 CFA units are fighting the blaze with support from Forest fire Management.
   An image posted to social media by the Wonga Park CFA on Tuesday night showed thick terrain glowing bright orange against the night sky.
   A heatwave warning has been issued for Victoria and temperatures are expected to reach more than 30 degrees for the next three days.

urn:contentItem:680T-B851-JD34-V1B7-00000-00Thieves caught on camera2023-04-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisThieves caught on cameraJessica Howard

Three men aged in their 20s have been filmed illegally cutting down trees for firewood in a forest near Casterton.

The South Australian men stole the red gum wood in September and October last year unbeknown to the fact they were being filmed on concealed cameras, which were planted in the Nangeela State Forest by Conservation Regulator authorised officers.

The Conservation Regulator set up the cameras as part of an operation targeting illegal firewood operations along the South Australian border.

Two of the men received infringements for illegal off-road driving under the Land Conservation (Vehicle Control) Regulations 2013, while all three were fined for cutting and taking the timber, a breach of the Forests Act 1958.

The fines totalled $4810.

Forest and wildlife officer for the Barwon South West region, Simon Donald, said the fines should serve as a reminder to anyone thinking about taking timber from parks and forests.

"They will be caught and face consequences - no matter where they live," he said in a statement.

"Anyone illegally taking timber from public land is destroying wildlife habitat and putting our threatened native species at risk."

It's illegal in Victoria to cut and take timber from standing trees, or take fallen trees or branches from public land without authorisation.

The Conservation Regulator is targeting illegal firewood theft through Operation Hollows, a partnership with Parks Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Authorised officers regularly patrol forests, parks and reserves and will penalise anyone attempting to take firewood illegally.

Anyone with information about illegal firewood theft or other environmental crimes can make an anonymous report to the state's Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action by calling 136 186.

urn:contentItem:67KX-NCH1-JD34-V142-00000-00CFA crews battle blazes2023-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisCFA crews battle blazesJenny Denton

Twenty-one CFA units turned out to a grass fire at Meering West-Quambatook on Tuesday evening, which the CFA was notified about at 5.30pm.

A helitanker from Bendigo was called in to fight the fire, which reportedly spread from the corner of Meering West and Lehmann roads in Meering West.

Crews had the blaze under control by 7pm.

Meanwhile 50 ground units and six aircraft were continuing to battle a grass fire at Flowerdale which was 300 hectares in size and growing.

The fire, which had been burning since 2.40pm, was not yet under control at 8pm.

Bulldozers and Forest Fire Management crews were also on the scene.

IN OTHER NEWS:

Firefighters trained to quickly reload large water bombers Reflecting on 40 years of service to Victoria Police In an update at 7.35pm the CFA said houses were under threat and asset protection had been implemented.

The fire was burning up a hill in a northerly direction.

A "watch and act warning" issued by VicEmergency was upgraded to an emergency warning in the late afternoon, with the community advised it was too late to safely leave and anyone in the area should immediately shelter indoors.

Around the state strong winds saw firefighters responding to smoke sightings and downed trees as well as fire outbreaks.

urn:contentItem:695Y-XHG1-JD3N-52FW-00000-00Indonesia caught short for fire season2023-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 13Indonesia caught short for fire seasonAMANDA HODGE, DIAN SEPTIARI, JAKARTA

Indonesia's national disaster agency has warned it has less than half the waterbombing helicopters needed to cope with a ferocious forest fire season as the country enters its most severe dry since 2019.

Fires have been burning out of control in six provinces this week, while recent satellite imagery shows the number of "hotspots" nationwide - indicating land or forest fires - quadrupled to 14,437 between July and August.

Authorities are warning the country is headed for a repeat of 2019 when extreme conditions caused more than 1.6 million hectares of peatlands and forests to burn, sending smoke over large parts of Indonesia as well as Singapore and parts of Malaysia. The Indonesian economy lost an estimated $US5.2bn ($8bn).

National disaster mitigation agency (BNPB) chief Suharyanto said on Thursday that Russia's war on Ukraine meant there was now a shortage of helicopters to call on in emergencies.

"We should have a minimum of 50 units in Indonesia when El Nino occurs. But now, there are only 22 available, and we have deployed them all across Indonesia," Mr Suharyanto told a parliamentary committee, referring to the dry weather pattern caused by elevated surface temperature in parts of the Pacific Ocean. "In the past, when Ukraine and Russia were not at war, we could get helicopters from there. But now they are fighting, so it is difficult." Firefighters this week tried cloud seeding affected areas to induce rain, but a lack of cloud cover hampered those efforts, he said.

Eddy Hermawan, a climatology professor with the National Research and Innovation Agency, said the severe conditions were the result of an El Nino event coinciding with a positive phase of the Indian Ocean Dipole, which also brought drier weather to Indonesia.

The two weather patterns are predicted to peak in November and December, when the risk of forest fires and transboundary haze will be highest.

"November and December will be critical because December is typically wet but this time there will be no rain," Professor Hermawan said.

That convergence would also intensify air pollution, which had recently reached hazardous levels in Jakarta. "Now we have two options; induce rain from the north or use groundwater to clean (mist) the air, which I think is suicide because if we continue to take groundwater we are just exacerbating land subsidence," he said. "The northern part of Java might as well learn from Saudi Arabia how to desalinate seawater." Indonesia is experiencing extended drought across large agricultural tracts of Java, the country's rice bowl, as well as impoverished Papua, and the government is having to import rice to make up a shortfall of more than a million tonnes.

President Joko Widodo said this week he had raised the issue with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet, Bangladesh President Mohammed Shahabuddin, India's Narendra Modi and Chinese Premier Li Qiang. His administration was now stockpiling for the year ahead.

But on Friday he conceded the government was struggling to secure supplies as other countries sought to shore up their food security. "If you want to import, the goods are very hard to get right now ... because countries want to save their own people and feed their own people," he said. Peatland fires occur every year in Indonesia - largely as a result of wide-scale drainage for agricultural development which makes them more flammable - but are more intense and widespread in El Nino years. A comprehensive study last year into the effects of Indonesia's peatland fires found the resulting air pollution caused the premature deaths annually of an average 33,100 adults and 2900 infants in Sumatra and Kalimantan alone.

urn:contentItem:65XT-8CF1-JD34-V3R4-00000-00Government seeks 300 firefighters across regional Victoria2022-07-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 9Government seeks 300 firefighters across regional Victoria

THE state government is seeking 300 forest firefighters to help keep Victorians safe over the coming fire season.

Recruitment has opened for more project firefighters to work with Forest Fire Management Victoria throughout summer, with project firefighters based at more than 80 locations throughout the state.

The new positions are for seasonal roles including general firefighters, fire support officers and rappel crews.

Successful recruits will undertake emergency response activities, planned burning, pest and weed control, road maintenance and other land management activities. Eighteen positions are dedicated for Australian Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people, helping Traditional Owners to care for Country and lead cultural burning.

The new recruits will add to Victoria's existing 300 project firefighters who are supported by more than 2000 permanent staff who can be called on to perform emergency roles when required.

Minister for Environment and Climate Action Lily D'Ambrosio said anyone keen to work outdoors and want to be part of a diverse and inclusive team that helped protect Victorian communities and the environment should consider applying.

Crews will work alongside key fire management agencies including the Country Fire Authority and Fire Rescue Victoria.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said project firefighters could expect to face a variety of work challenges.

"You could be operating heavy machinery one week and responding to an emergency the next - no two days are the same," he said.

"Successful recruits will be fully trained and get the opportunity to work with experienced staff from a range of fire management agencies right across the state, and potentially nationally and internationally if required."

Applications for project firefighter positions close on Sunday, July 31.

urn:contentItem:66P1-5PP1-DY47-5361-00000-00While parts of Victoria flood, seasonal firefighters train for potentially intense bushfire season2022-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisWhile parts of Victoria flood, seasonal firefighters train for potentially intense bushfire season

A new cohort of seasonal firefighters have undergone training ahead of a potentially intense summer fire season, with recent wet weather leading to an increased growth in wild grasses and other fuels.

As floods continue to impact parts of Victoria, the Country Fire Authority is warning that intense grass fires could be a threat during the upcoming summer.

A wet winter and spring has led to increased growth in wild grasses which have the potential to feed bushfires once conditions dry out.

But additional help is on the way with 25 seasonal firefighting recruits put through their paces at a rigorous training course in Mildura this week.

Robert Tucker, operations coordinator at the Mallee work centre for Forest Fire Management Victoria, said the recruits would respond to various emergency situations including fires and floods, while also learning crucial land management skills.

"We've got a really great bunch of guys and girls who are really eager to absorb knowledge and new skills," he said.

"There will be another camp mid-November which will have another 20 or 30 staff there including quite a few Indigenous people."

Giving back to country

The training and subsequent work is an opportunity for the recruits to help out their local community.

Stephanie Carter said everyone in the course came from different backgrounds and were all willing to have a go.

"It's something I always wanted to do, return to country, learn about the land and the impact that the weather has," she said

Former police officer John Kutchel said with the current flooding events taking place, the training had come at an ideal time.

"There's plenty more rain on the way, so there is every chance we will be out there pretty soon sandbagging and helping out where needed."

A much-needed boost

This year Forest Fire Management Victoria has recruited 92 preliminary firefighters in the Loddon Mallee Region.

Robert Tucker said they were lucky with recent recruitment numbers, following a lack of staffing last year.

"With more staff it means if we have a major flood or fire event we can help out the community," he said.

"We can also do rotations of task forces and other teams as well."

The latest recruits will soon be deployed to fire stations at Hattah, Mildura, Robinvale, Swan Hill, Speed, Underbool, Werrimull, Rainbow, Avoca, Bendigo, Echuca, Castlemaine, Cohuna, Heathcote, Inglewood, Maryborough, Rushworth, Macedon and St Arnaud.

urn:contentItem:67FN-7NJ1-F0J6-J255-00000-00Controlled burn-off planned near Beaufort2023-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisControlled burn-off planned near Beaufort

A planned burn is scheduled near Beaufort this week, as fire authorities take advantage of cooler conditions to reduce fuel loads.

The burn, a combined Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA operation, is planned near the Beaufort-Larkin Road, about three kilometres north of Beaufort.

The fire could be lit any time within the next 10 days, pending suitable conditions.

In an update from FFMV on Wednesday, residents were warned there will be smoke in the area when the burnoff begins.

"Weather conditions and fuel moisture levels at the burn site are being monitored and safety checks carried out in preparation for the burn. If conditions are not suitable, the burn may be postponed," the update states.

"Note that some burns are carried out in stages, with part of the burn completed, and crews returning later to carry out further work within the burn area."

Residents should be aware there may be smoke this week from a planned burn near Daylesford, on the Old Tom Track.

An update from Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA notes the burn-off could be ignited "at any time within the next 10 days", if weather conditions remain suitable.

The planned burn will be about four kilometres southwest of Daylesford.

"Weather conditions and fuel moisture levels at the burn site are being monitored and safety checks carried out in preparation for the burn. If conditions are not suitable, the burn may be postponed," the update states.

urn:contentItem:687B-49F1-F0JP-W4W0-00000-00RUNNING TO TROUBLE2023-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 30RUNNING TO TROUBLESarah Booth

As he walked across Victoria - from Mallacoota, where trees still bear the black scars of fire, to the Hotham Valley, where decades-old disasters still haunt communities - former paramedic Tony Pearce thought about the mates he had lost.

He thought about the mental health toll their jobs took on frontline emergency workers, including himself.

Despite enduring conditions that ranged from subzero temperatures to relentless heatwaves, the now Inspector-General for Emergency Management navigated his 1500km, 50-day charity trek, saying it was an easier challenge than the one faced by many first responders.

It had an end in sight.

He knows how hard his colleagues' battles have been, -because he endured similar after responding to the devastating 1997 Thredbo landslide, being involved in the rescue of sole survivor Stuart Diver, whose wife Sally died.

Mr Pearce said he and his colleagues struggled afterwards, and his health declined in the weeks after -he returned to Melbourne.

"I was getting angry or my behaviour was unpredictable," he said. "I was worried â€¦ what would happen next." He said, in hindsight, Thredbo was not the immediate cause of his stress but the final straw.

And while he got the help he needed, he said it may never have reached that stage if there had been more support for early intervention and prevention in the two "particularly traumatic" years beforehand.

That's why he walked: to raise money for such programs, offered by the Emergency Services Foundation, and to start a conversation.

On most days local emergency crews walked alongside him, inviting him back to their stations or units that night.

"We're on the Princes Highway with trucks going past at 100 km/h right beside you â€¦ and it's almost like there's an invisible bubble we're in and they just started talking," the ESF chair said.

And as the skyline changed - from the city lights of Melbourne to tree-lined horizons further afield - so, too, did these conversations.

In smaller towns, crews faced the awful, but seemingly inevitable, tragedy of arriving at scenes to find they knew the victims, along with dwindling volunteer numbers.

Mr Pearce said the people who dropped everything for their neighbours feared they had no back-up if they stepped away to help themselves.

"There are so few volunteers, many of them working across two or three emergency service volunteer organisations, and therefore they are the response to everything," he said.

The thought that she had failed her community was something Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA volunteer firefighter Erika Lind feared.

She said one of her hardest memories was not a graphic scene of horror, but the tears of a farmer who had lost his livestock and the knowledge that she could not help him.

"Seeing your community grieving and you've not been able to do enough to help â€¦ that weighs on my heart," she said. "You just want to rescue everybody." The relentless nature of forest fire fighting - campaigns can last for weeks - began to -affect her mental health, but she said she ignored the signs until a "sliding doors" moment with a Canadian firefighter while travelling.

She said chatting to him felt like seeing her story "30 years in the future". "He was describing the same experiences and feelings that I had," she said. She credited walking, time in nature and speaking with both colleagues and professionals to identify triggers, symptoms and understand the science -behind our reactions to stress, as key to improving her health.

But in a small town called Cobungra, a firefighter admitted that opening up could be difficult.

Omeo third lieutenant David Butler said the trauma of the 2003 fires - the state's worst in more than 60 years - were "still raw".

"There's still people that will shed a tear from the 2003 fires," he said. "The 2019-20 fires â€¦ I don't think the impact of that will fully raise its head for a while." Lifesaver and former detective sergeant Peter Bellion is familiar with the lasting impact of trauma, having retired in 2016 with chronic PTSD.

After more than 20 years -investigating major crashes, he was left with a long list of anniversaries - from attending colleagues' fatal accidents and holding dying girls on the side of the road to the 2007 Kerang train disaster that claimed 11 lives.

The dates are etched in his memory, and on the day of our interview a well-intentioned remembrance post for a fallen colleague had brought him "straight back to the site".

"I can describe in detail â€¦ where everything was," he said.

He said the trauma manifested into physical symptoms, from psoriasis that prompted his first doctor visit and still hasn't left to health scares -including a concerning (but now treated) bowel cancer screening result.

"I ended up with 35 per cent permanent injury to the brain," he said. "We were going to the trouble when others would run away.

"It's a natural, physiological and psychological reaction to what you've had to experience." Mr Pearce and the hundreds of emergency responders who supported his trek know the path forward is complex.

But they hope this campaign can soften a stigma that they say still exists in their industry and spark conversations that can prevent much harder ones further down the track.
